description: This course is an introduction to programming and gives a good base for further studies within computational science, but it's also suited for those who just wish to understand what programming is. The course doesn't presuppose any knowledge of programming. It'll be given a beginners introduction to Python and how to develop algorithms, including the use of lists, files, and communication with the user. Particular emphasis is placed on object-oriented programming.

This course introduces fundamental concepts of calculus, including limits, derivatives, and integrals. Students will learn various techniques for solving mathematical problems involving functions and their rates of change. Applications of calculus in physics, engineering, and economics will be explored.

This course provides an introduction to the principles of quantum mechanics. Topics covered include wave-particle duality, Schr√∂dinger's equation, operators, and the mathematical formalism of quantum mechanics. Applications of quantum mechanics in atomic and molecular systems will be discussed.

This course covers the fundamental data structures and algorithms used in computer science. Topics include arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, graphs, sorting algorithms, and searching algorithms. Students will analyze the efficiency and performance of different data structures and algorithms.

This course introduces the principles of microeconomics, which focus on individual economic agents such as consumers, firms, and markets. Topics include supply and demand, market equilibrium, consumer behavior, production and costs, and market structures. The course also explores the role of government in the economy.

This course introduces students to the basic principles and methodologies of experimental psychology. Topics covered include research design, data collection, statistical analysis, and interpretation of psychological experiments. Students will gain hands-on experience in conducting experiments and analyzing data.

This course provides an introduction to classical mechanics, which is the branch of physics that deals with the motion of macroscopic objects. Topics covered include Newton's laws of motion, conservation laws, rotational motion, oscillations, and gravitation. Applications of classical mechanics in engineering and astronomy will be discussed.

This course introduces the fundamental concepts of linear algebra. Topics covered include vector spaces, matrices, systems of linear equations, determinants, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors. Applications of linear algebra in engineering, computer science, and physics will be discussed.

This course explores the principles and techniques of artificial intelligence. Topics covered include knowledge representation, problem-solving, search algorithms, machine learning, natural language processing, and intelligent agents. Students will develop AI systems and apply them to real-world problems.

This course introduces the principles of macroeconomics, which focus on aggregate economic variables such as national income, inflation, unemployment, and economic growth. Topics covered include national income accounting, monetary and fiscal policy, international trade, and exchange rates. The course also examines the impact of macroeconomic factors on businesses and individuals.

This course provides an introduction to molecular biology, which is the study of biological macromolecules and their interactions in cellular processes. Topics covered include DNA replication, transcription, translation, gene regulation, and recombinant DNA technology. Students will gain practical laboratory skills in molecular biology techniques.

This course covers the fundamental concepts of discrete mathematics. Topics include logic, set theory, functions, relations, combinatorics, graph theory, and formal proof techniques. Students will develop problem-solving and critical thinking skills through the study of discrete mathematical structures.

This course provides an overview of world history from prehistoric times to the present. Major civilizations, events, and historical processes will be examined, with a focus on political, social, cultural, and economic developments. The course aims to develop students' understanding of the interconnectedness of global history.

This course explores the history of art from ancient civilizations to the modern era. Major artistic movements, styles, and works of art will be examined, with an emphasis on understanding the cultural, social, and historical contexts in which they were created. Students will develop skills in visual analysis and interpretation.

This course examines the theories and practices of international relations, focusing on the interactions between states and non-state actors in the global arena. Topics covered include international cooperation and conflict, diplomacy, international organizations, global governance, and security issues. The course also explores the impact of globalization on international relations.

This course provides an introduction to organic chemistry, which is the study of the structure, properties, composition, reactions, and synthesis of organic compounds. Topics covered include organic nomenclature, functional groups, stereochemistry, reaction mechanisms, and spectroscopic methods for structure determination. Students will gain hands-on experience in organic synthesis and characterization.

This course explores the principles and institutions of constitutional law, focusing on the legal framework of government and the protection of individual rights and freedoms. Topics covered include constitutional interpretation, separation of powers, judicial review, fundamental rights, and constitutional amendments. The course also examines constitutional law in a comparative context.

This course provides an introduction to thermodynamics, which is the study of energy and its transformations in physical systems. Topics covered include the laws of thermodynamics, thermodynamic properties, heat engines, entropy, and phase transitions. Applications of thermodynamics in engineering and environmental science will be discussed.

This course introduces the principles and techniques of statistical analysis. Topics covered include descriptive statistics, probability theory, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, regression analysis, and analysis of variance. Students will learn to use statistical software to analyze and interpret data from various fields.
